items.item_details:
The Board of Trustees offers an opportunity for the public to address the Board in four sections of the agenda: on matters of concern about Closed Session items; on matters not appearing on the agenda; on action items contained in the Consent Agenda; and prior to voting on any item contained in the Action Agenda. Each speaker is encouraged to submit a comment card to the Board clerk in order to be recognized to speak.
	Per Board Policy, three minutes may be allotted to each speaker with a maximum of 30 minutes per subject. No action or discussion shall be undertaken on any public comments except that members of the Board or its staff may briefly respond to or ask a question for clarification regarding statements made or questions posed by persons addressing the Board under this agenda item.
	For information and disability access to materials, call 408-270-6402. Meetings are held in a location accessible to the disabled.

items.item_details:
A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the following Management Actions:
	 
	 
1.    Resignation
	 
Coon, W. David, President of Evergreen Valley College is resigning. His last day will be 11/30/2010. 
	 
	 
2.    Change of Status 
	 
Kuniko Hay, Vice President of Instruction, is to serve as acting president for Evergreen Valley College in David W. Coon’s absence from October 28, 2010 to November 26, 2010 and from December 1, 2010 to December 16, 2010.
	 
Ms. Hay will receive 5% out-of-class payment added to her M-34-4 salary for her assignment as Acting President.  (See attached).
	 
For the period of December 17, 2010 thru January 2, 2011, Irma Archuleta, Vice President of Student Services, is to serve as Acting President. Assignment is less than 30 days.
	 
3.    Interim President Search
	 
The search for an interim president is currently underway. The tentative schedule is as follows:
	 
Recruitment period:                                   November 1 – November 24
Interviews:                                                December 3 – December 6
Submit finalist for Board Approval:              December 14, 2010.
	 
The Interim President is anticipated to serve January 1, 2011 to June 30, 2011.

Educational Code 81655 stipulates that no contract is an enforceable obligation of the district until it has been approved by the Board of Trustees. District policy adopted on April 10, 2007 establishes the authority of certain administrators to approve contracts under the bid limit prior to formal Board approval. All contracts and purchase orders exceeding the bid limit (currently $78,500) should have prior board approval as a separate Board item.
	 
This consent item presents for Board approval: all purchase orders for this period, which includes all purchase orders for administratively-approved contracts exceeding $750, as well as additional contracts that although are not executed by way of purchase order are deemed appropriate to be added by the Purchasing Department.

items.item_details:
Board Policy 7080.203 defines Class III records as, including, but not limited to, detailed records relating to:  records basic to an audit, including those relating to attendance, average daily attendance, or a business or financial transaction (purchase orders, invoices, warrants, ledger sheets, canceled checks and stubs, student body and cafeteria fund records, etc.), and detailed records used in the preparation of any other report.
	 
Board Policy 7080.204 states that Class III records basic to an audit shall not be destroyed until after the third July 1st succeeding the completion of the audit required by Education Code 84040 or of any other legally required audit, or after the ending date of any retention period required by any agency other than the State of California, whichever date is later.
	 
Fiscal Services has the following Class III records that meet the three-year criteria for destruction:
	 
Invoices from Fiscal Year 2003-2004
Canceled Checks from Fiscal Year 2003-2004
Refund Requests from Fiscal Year 2003-2004
Journal Vouchers from Fiscal Year 2003-2004
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the destruction of records as listed per Section 7080.302 of the Retention and Destruction of Records under Board Policies.

items.item_details: In collaboration with the Santa Clara and San Benito Counties Building Trades Council (BTC), the National Labor College, and San José City College the Institute submitted the final application to obtain funding for the development of a construction management program.  Under the Consolidated Appropriations Act of 2010, a Congressionally-Directed grant was officially awarded on September 24, 2010 for $368,000. The timeframe for program activities is October 1, 2010 through September 30th, 2011.  The congressional intention of the award is for the California Construction College to train students for careers in construction management, strategically link career pathways in the construction trades through the local K-12 system, and develop a consortium of regional community colleges and local trades unions to articulate agreements so that union trainees at regional JATCs can access more community college credits.

items.item_details:
The U.S. Department of Education under the Title V Hispanic-Serving Institutions Program has awarded EVC a five-year grant totaling $2,875,000.
	 
EVC has developed a program to address low success, persistence and transfer rates of Hispanic students, particularly first generation students enrolled in math, science and English. The overarching goal is to institutionalize practices that increase the college’s capacity to meet the needs of the Hispanic students and to change the culture of EVC so that Hispanic student success becomes a top institutional priority.  The grant is comprised of four components with each component addressing identified goals and objectives. 
Component 1:  Program Innovation and Expansion
Component 2:  Faculty Professional Development
Component 3:  Supplemental Instruction/Peer Tutoring Support
Component 4:  Retention Management System 
	 
Positions associated with the implementation of this grant will be submitted to the Board for approval at the November 30, 2010, meeting.

items.item_details: The Middle Eastern Studies Consortium was created to establish Middle Eastern Studies in our region. San Jose State University (the lead institution), Santa Clara University and San Jose City College will work together and allocate resources to develop new courses, provide resources to students and expand knowledge about the Middle East. During the first year of this three year-grant cycle, San Jose City College will develop two new Global Studies courses focused on the Middle East , as well as, Arabic language courses. In addition, campus based activities such as speakers, film screenings,  and culturally based celebrations will be supported. Limited funding is also available for faculty conference attendance and student study abroad in accordance with existing Board travel policy standards.

items.item_details:
FAM-PACT/Family Pact (Planning, Access, Care and Treatment) Program
 
Student Health Services (SHS), SJCC, participates in the FAM-PACT program by providing no-cost family planning services to low-income students.  SHS provides personal and confidential health care services by Family Practice Physicians & Public Health and Clinic nurses.  Services include prevention of unplanned pregnancies, basic reproductive assessments and prevention, screening and treatment of STIs (sexually transmitted infections).  After the services are provided, SHS submits an encounter form for reimbursement for services rendered.  In turn, the State reimburses SHS for the services provided to students by our health care professional.  All reimbursements are used to support the students, including, but not limited to, free/low cost medications, supplies, and other services and the staff including the Medical Director.  The FAM-PACT program requires a Medical Director for participation.
 
Student Health Services, SJCC received $17,065.97 of Family Pact revenue for services rendered.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees please accept this revenue and appropriation.

On August 3, 1990 President George H.W. Bush declared the month of November as National American Indian Heritage Month. This landmark bill read in part that “the President has authorized and requested to call upon Federal, State and local Governments, groups and organizations and the people of the United States to observe such month with appropriate programs, ceremonies and activities.” This commemorative month aims to provide a platform for native people to share their culture, traditions, music, crafts, dance, and ways and concepts of life. 
	 
The San Jose/Evergreen Community College District supports the designation of November as National American Indian Heritage Month.

Chancellor Cepeda will provide a legislative update.

The District desires a way to financially support the implementation of the 2025 Educational Master Plans of the colleges that were approved by the Board of Trustees in July 2010 and the Facilities Master Plan of the District, which will be completed in December 2010.  These plans require necessary funding for facility, technology and basic infrastructure repairs that are required for instructional programs and services that support student success.
	 
There are currently no state resources allocated for these purposes, and given the economic condition of the state, resources will likely be minimally available in the future.  The District has successfully passed Measure I in 1998 and Measure G in 2004 to support capital projects in the District, but the majority of the projects associated with these bonds have been completed.
	 
Recent surveys had indicated community support for those projects which upgrade and replace classrooms and labs, improve infrastructure, increase energy efficiency and reduce operating costs, ensure accessibility for disabled students, and make sure that technology is current for teaching and learning.
	 
Resolution 080510-1, approved by the Board on August 5, 2010, authorized a Prop. 39 General Obligation Bond Election, Measure G, on November 2, 2010 in the amount of $268,000,000.  The results of the election are that the measure passed with  58% support.  Bonnie Moss, Vice-President at Tramutola & Associates and David Casnocha, Bond Counsel, will discuss the outcome of the election and next steps relative to election certification and implementation.

The State Chancellor's Office requires districts to prepare an Annual Financial and Budget Report (CCFS-311).  The report is the vehicle for summarizing and communicating the results of budgetary decisions and transactions of all governmental, proprietary, and fiduciary funds for each fiscal year.  The information is then compiled by the State Chancellor's Office.
	 
The attached Fiscal Year 2009-2010 Annual Financial and Budget Report (CCFS-311) is presented to the Board of Trustees as an informational item.
